samples.text: I consider this proof of life beyond Earth. The only other explanation is that Trump visited this world and farted, which is unlikely because it would require time travel, as the gasses measured were emitted more than 100 years ago. www.theguardian.comscience2025...

Sound on Mars is different than on Earth due to the planet’s thin, carbon dioxide-rich atmosphere, which causes sounds to be quieter, slower, more muffled, with lower frequencies being more prominent Mars sound unique

New Mars study highlights siderite, a mineral that traps CO2. Lead author Ben Tutolo says learning how these minerals form on Mars helps us understand how to do it here, eg use of Carbonates to fight climate change. Habitability is fragile. Something happened to Mars that didn’t happen to Earth.
Which is ironic, as everybody knows reviewer 2s are extremophiles, evolving in hydrothermal vents.

Our position in this solar system, this "Goldilocks" zone that's perfect for the necessities of life on this planet to exist it's so unique. There's definitely life elsewhere, statistically. But we haven't met each other yet. So for now, we only have this and each other.

Extraordinary claims, such as alien life, will require extraordinary evidence. A single biosignature gas, sniffed out in the atmosphere of the planet is unlikely to be enough. A much more thorough understanding of how the planet’s geology, atmosphere, climate, and star interact will likely be needed

And then you've got I ask yourself the age-old question of what comes first habitability or life, especially when you're talking about gases consistent with life being found on hydrogen rich planets, just because it's uninhabitable for us doesn't mean no life!
Chemical Hints on a Distant Planet Offer 'Strongest Evidence Yet' for Life Outside Our Solar System, Astronomers Say - Smithsonian Magazine
In other news scientists have found two gasses which are generated on earth by living organisms on an another planet. They haven’t found what’s generating those gases yet
Is a sub-oceanic ice layer part of the definition of hycean worlds? I see how that would preclude hydrothermal vents, which would otherwise introduce chemicals.

Impressive detective work. It’s possible that previous reports of detection of methane on Mars are contamination. Will await results from rover after conducting the suggested tests. agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.comdoi10.1029...
Correction gases that as far as we know only occur through biological processes. We don't know for absolutely sure it can happen elsewise.

There isn't even consensus that there is water on the planet. Is it possible life exists on that planet? Absolutely. But there is ZERO proof and the evidence is sketchy at best. Don't jump to conclusions. More data is being collected.

Yeah, the bit in the article about how the planet would have 1000x more dimethyl sulfide than Earth makes me think that there’s something else going on here- some alternative non-living process we haven’t found. Admittedly, well out of my depth here

And on our planet, the only one we know of with life, life lives damn near everywhere. In cracks sealed up a million years ago, with water and it's own sealed ecosphere, we've found life. Volcanic vents, lousy with life.

Researchers have detected the chemical fingerprints of gases that on Earth are produced only by biological processes.

Counting krill from space? Yes, actually. Scientists are using satellites to track these tiny sea creatures, revealing their massive impact on our planet’s health and climate. Learn how the smallest organisms are making big shifts in climate science. Krillforthekill www.bbc.comnewsarticle...

Brett, I gotta be honest. I genuinely hope the scientists are right here. I really do. They're supposing there is reason to believe carbon based life forms are there and the signal being produced is indicative of life on the planet. Man, that would be so cool. I wish Carl was here to experience it.

Sadly I think this wishful thinking it's unlikely life would evolve and thrive on a tidally locked super earth orbiting a dim flaring red dwarf. Dimethyl sulphide could be produced by chemical reactions in a methane atmosphere. Still, it's an exciting hope. www.bbc.co.uknewsarticle...
Seen this, and it doesn't account for the AMOUNT of DMS the paper claims to have detected, which is substantially greater than in Earth's atmosphere!

The reason the Hydrogen Sulfide is such a big deal is that it's generally pretty unstable. As an example, WASP-39b's atmosphere also measured thanks to JSWT breaks down H2S into sulfur dioxide.

Possible origins We’re looking at some form of life that can - Thrive in a hydrogen-rich atmosphere - Possibly live in or on top of a global ocean - Generate large amounts of DMSpotentially thousands of times more than Earth

Read some of it and it seems like by far the strongest case for an extrasolar biosphere yet, but also not enough to definitively claim presence of a biosphere Their DMS reading is 3-sigma and is a LOT of the stuff.

And if we find life in our solar system it's likely bad news for them. Because the odds of us contaminating it, or fucking things up are so high. Even with the abundance of caution, life is aggressive.
If Planet Nine exists, this is how we will find it, either through direct observation or by identifying a statistically significant number of TNOs that support the Planet Nine hypothesis.
Basically, the 'water' is too hot. But you have to take into consideration the life forms we've found near our own thermal vents. So, the possibility def exists.

Specifically, they think it is a "Hycean" world a term coined in 2021 by Madhusudhan et al. a planet made mostly of water, with a hydrogen atmosphere. In many cases, the water layer on such a world would get so hot that it goes supercritical. But with the right conditions, it can be temperate.

Think this is pretty mistaken - the recent findings regarding K2-18b are orders of magnitude stronger than the ones from 2023. Claims of extrasolar biospheres are typically met with ENTIRELY WARRANTED skepticism from scientists, but this looks like it may actually be the real deal, for once!
This is the strongest evidence to date for a biological activity beyond the solar system The truth really is out there. apple.newsAGrURTgLCT7y...

Webb just upended assumptions about a star swallowing a planet it didn’t balloon into a red giant Webb shows the planet spiralled in slowly until consumed. The result? A hot disk of gas, cooler dust clouds, and chemical signatures like carbon monoxide.

One thing caught my eye - 422 K 150 C photospheric temperature at 1 mbar and fluxes of those gases at 20x earth levels. What imaginable life could survive at those temperatures and implied biologic mass?

These, combined together, may indicate a strong possibility of life on another planet, albeit a planet we, Nitrogen-rich atmosphere enjoyers, could never survive on. This is huge, and our first real evidence albeit not conclusive of life on another world.

Is there anybody out there? Scientists hail strongest evidence’ so far for life beyond our solar system www.theguardian.comscience2025...
Yeah, but no. CH4 and CO2 are not only created through biology. We have many planets in our own solar system that contain these gasses. It might be a sign of life or is might not be.

Before they can really say they think they have discovered life on another planet, they need to confirm what they think they've seen to damn near 100% try everything possible to rule out all the other ways this gas could have been created through some other process
I’ve never believed that were the only lump of rock in the solar system with life on it.

Well, they’ve detected - for the 2nd time since 2023 - dimethyl sulfide which, on earth at least, is a waste product of living organisms you can smell it when you’re on a beach. There may yet be chemical processes on other worlds which can produce it without life, and much more research is needed.

Sensational claims of life on another planet are just that, claims. What would we need for those claims to be verified? More work from independent groups, more data and a real look at non-biological alternatives, which could take years, or forever. www.newscientist.comarticle2477...

Do theywe know anything about the siderite paragenesis? What if it were late phase, when its saturation had increased because of precipitation of sulphates etc such that the only components left were FeII and some CO2? Or is that built into their model?

They found evidence of gasses that we only know of being created by the presence of biological life. It could be some unknown process creating them though, with a 0.3% chance it's a fluke altogether. www.reuters.comsciencescie...
save me planet K2-18b with an hydrogen-rich atmosphere and no computer jobs
